Class Remove_Linked_List_Elements

java.lang.Object
Remove_Linked_List_Elements
public class Remove_Linked_List_Elements extends Object
LeetCode 203: Remove Linked List Elements

Problem Description:
Given the head of a singly linked list and an integer val, remove all nodes of the linked list that have node.val == val, and return the head of the modified list.

Sample Input / Output: 


 Example 1:
 Input:  head = [1,2,6,3,4,5,6], val = 6
 Output: [1,2,3,4,5]

 Example 2:
 Input:  head = [], val = 1
 Output: []

 Example 3:
 Input:  head = [7,7,7,7], val = 7
 Output: []

Constraints:

  • 0 invalid input: '<'= n invalid input: '<'= 10^5 (n = number of nodes)
  • Node values are within 32-bit signed integer range

  • Method Details

    • removeElementsArrayList

      public ListNode removeElementsArrayList(ListNode head, int val)
      Removes all nodes equal to val by collecting values into an ArrayList and then rebuilding a new linked list.

      Approach 1: Using ArrayList (Filter → Rebuild)

      Detailed Steps:

      1. Initialize an empty list:
        • Create ArrayList<Integer> kept = new ArrayList<>();.
        • This will temporarily hold only the values we want to keep.
      2. Traverse the original linked list:
        • Start from head and move until null.
        • For each node:
          • If node.val != val, add it to kept.
          • If node.val == val, skip it (do not add).
        • Invariant: At the end, kept contains exactly the values that should remain in the final list, in the same order.
      3. Rebuild the linked list:
        • Create a dummy node: ListNode dummy = new ListNode(0);.
        • Maintain a tail pointer tail = dummy;.
        • Iterate through kept:
          • For each value v, create a new node new ListNode(v).
          • Attach it to tail.next and move tail forward.
        • At the end, return dummy.next as the head of the new list.
      4. Edge Cases:
        • If head == null, the traversal does nothing → return null.
        • If every node equals val, then kept is empty → return null.
        • If no node equals val, then kept has all values → rebuild gives the same list.

      Complexity:

      • Time: O(n) — one full traversal to collect, one to rebuild.
      • Space: O(n) — extra ArrayList stores up to n values.

    • removeElementsEfficient

      public ListNode removeElementsEfficient(ListNode head, int val)
      Removes all nodes equal to val directly by relinking nodes in place.

      Approach 2: Efficient In-Place Deletion (Dummy + One Pass)

      Detailed Steps:

      1. Create a dummy sentinel node:
        • ListNode dummy = new ListNode(0, head); — dummy points to the real head.
        • Using dummy avoids special handling when the head itself must be deleted.
      2. Initialize a traversal pointer:
        • Set current = dummy.
        • We will always check current.next, not current, so that we can modify links if needed.
        • Invariant: all nodes before current are guaranteed to be valid (do not equal val).
      3. Traverse the list:
        • While current.next != null:
        • If current.next.val == val:
          • Unlink that node using current.next = current.next.next.
          • Do not move current forward — because the new current.next might also have value val.
        • Else (value is fine):
          • Advance current = current.next.
      4. End condition:
        • Loop finishes when current.next == null → no more nodes left.
        • Return dummy.next as the possibly-updated head.

      Why "do not advance after deletion" is necessary:

      • Example: list = [6,6,6,3], val = 6.
      • If we advanced after the first deletion, we would skip checking the second 6.
      • By staying in place, we ensure consecutive matches are also removed.

      Complexity:

      • Time: O(n) — each node checked once, deletions O(1).
      • Space: O(1) — only dummy and current pointers used.
